title: Pseudotumor cerebri comorbid with meningioma: A review and case series
patient: The patient is a 49-year-old woman who presented with left visual field cut (BMI of 27.45 kg/m2). Brain MRI revealed right parieto-occipital meningioma that abutted the superior sagittal sinus without hydrocephalus []. She had papilledema thought to be caused by venous obstruction. She denied headaches or tinnitus. The patient deferred lumbar puncture. A right frontal VP shunt was recommended for the treatment of PTC. Postoperatively, the patient reported significant symptom improvement and resolution of visual complaints. She denied any headaches, nausea, or vomiting and discontinued all medications. She returned to full-time work without any issues. At the patient's 1 year follow-up, she remained asymptomatic; however, imaging studies showed that the parieto-occipital meningioma increased in size. She elected to undergo gamma knife radiosurgery for treatment of the meningioma.
